questions.question: If <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>22</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Subtract 6 from both sides to get <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. Divide both sides by 4 to get <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable term first by performing inverse operations for addition or subtraction, then handle multiplication or division.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: What is the solution <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></math> to the system of equations <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></math> for <math><mi>y</mi></math> in the second equation: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, which simplifies to <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Substitute <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> into <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi></math> to find <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When one equation is already solved for a variable (like y = 3x), substitution is usually the fastest method.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><path d='M50 210 H350 M50 170 H350 M50 130 H350 M50 90 H350 M50 50 H350' stroke='#e0e0e0' stroke-width='1'/><path d='M100 250 V50 M150 250 V50 M200 250 V50 M250 250 V50 M300 250 V50 M350 250 V50' stroke='#e0e0e0' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='370' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='30' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='360' y='280' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>x</text><text x='30' y='30' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>y</text><g font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'><text x='50' y='270'>0</text><text x='100' y='270'>10</text><text x='150' y='270'>20</text><text x='200' y='270'>30</text><text x='250' y='270'>40</text><text x='300' y='270'>50</text><text x='350' y='270'>60</text></g><g font-size='12' text-anchor='end'><text x='40' y='255'>0</text><text x='40' y='215'>20</text><text x='40' y='175'>40</text><text x='40' y='135'>60</text><text x='40' y='95'>80</text><text x='40' y='55'>100</text></g><circle cx='100' cy='210' r='4' fill='black' /><circle cx='150' cy='180' r='4' fill='black' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='4' fill='black' /><circle cx='250' cy='120' r='4' fill='black' /><circle cx='300' cy='90' r='4' fill='black' /><line x1='50' y1='240' x2='350' y2='60' stroke='blue' stroke-dasharray='5,5' stroke-width='2' /></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A scatterplot with x-axis ranging from 0 to 60 and y-axis from 0 to 100. Grid lines are shown every 10 units on x and 20 units on y. Several data points show a positive linear trend. A dashed blue line of best fit passes through the points (10, 20), (30, 50), and (50, 80).
questions.question: The scatterplot above shows data points and a line of best fit. Based on the line of best fit, what is the predicted value of $y$ when $x = 30$?
questions.explanation:
To find the predicted value:
1. Locate $x = 30$ on the horizontal axis.
2. Move vertically upwards from $x = 30$ until you intersect the line of best fit.
3. From that intersection point, look horizontally to the left to read the corresponding value on the y-axis.

The line intersects $x=30$ exactly at the grid line for $y=50$.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' style='font-family: Arial, sans-serif;'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><path d='M50 210 H350 M50 170 H350 M50 130 H350 M50 90 H350 M50 50 H350' stroke='#f0f0f0' stroke-width='1'/><path d='M100 250 V50 M150 250 V50 M200 250 V50 M250 250 V50 M300 250 V50 M350 250 V50' stroke='#f0f0f0' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='370' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='30' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='360' y='280' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>x</text><text x='30' y='30' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>y</text><g font-size='12' text-anchor='middle'><text x='50' y='270'>0</text><text x='100' y='270'>10</text><text x='150' y='270'>20</text><text x='200' y='270'>30</text><text x='250' y='270'>40</text><text x='300' y='270'>50</text><text x='350' y='270'>60</text></g><g font-size='12' text-anchor='end'><text x='40' y='255'>0</text><text x='40' y='215'>20</text><text x='40' y='175'>40</text><text x='40' y='135'>60</text><text x='40' y='95'>80</text><text x='40' y='55'>100</text></g><line x1='50' y1='240' x2='350' y2='60' stroke='blue' stroke-dasharray='5,5' stroke-width='2' opacity='0.5'/><line x1='200' y1='250' x2='200' y2='150' stroke='red' stroke-width='3' stroke-dasharray='4,2'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='50' y2='150' stroke='red' stroke-width='3' stroke-dasharray='4,2'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='6' fill='red' /><text x='25' y='155' font-size='14' font-weight='bold' fill='red'>50</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The scatterplot with a red dashed path drawn. The path starts at 30 on the x-axis, goes up to the blue trend line, and then goes left to the y-axis, pointing clearly to the value 50.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a question mentions a 'line of best fit', ignore the individual data points. Read directly from the line, even if no specific data point exists at that location.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='250' height='200' viewBox='0 0 250 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><polygon points='40,160 200,160 40,40' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='40' y='140' width='20' height='20' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='110' y='180' font-size='14'>8</text><text x='20' y='100' font-size='14'>6</text><text x='130' y='90' font-size='14'>c</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Right triangle with legs of length 6 and 8. The hypotenuse is labeled c.
questions.question: The figure shows a right triangle with legs of lengths 6 and 8. What is the length of the hypotenuse, <math><mi>c</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Use the Pythagorean theorem <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Substitute the lengths: <math><msup><mn>6</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>8</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>64</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn></math>. Since <math><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn></math>, <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize common Pythagorean triples like 3-4-5 and 6-8-10 to solve these problems instantly without calculation.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><path d='M0 30 H300 M0 60 H300 M0 90 H300 M0 120 H300 M0 150 H300 M0 180 H300 M0 210 H300 M0 240 H300 M0 270 H300' stroke='#eee' stroke-width='1'/><path d='M30 0 V300 M60 0 V300 M90 0 V300 M120 0 V300 M150 0 V300 M180 0 V300 M210 0 V300 M240 0 V300 M270 0 V300' stroke='#eee' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='150' y1='290' x2='150' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)'/><line x1='10' y1='150' x2='290' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)'/><text x='280' y='170' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='160' y='20' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>y</text><line x1='60' y1='30' x2='270' y2='240' stroke='blue' stroke-width='3'/><circle cx='150' cy='60' r='5' fill='black'/><circle cx='240' cy='150' r='5' fill='black'/><text x='165' y='65' font-size='14' font-family='Arial'>(0, 3)</text><text x='245' y='140' font-size='14' font-family='Arial'>(3, 0)</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: The xy-plane with a grid. A blue line passes through two labeled points: the y-intercept at (0, 3) and the x-intercept at (3, 0). The line slopes downward from left to right.
questions.question: Which equation represents the line shown in the graph?
questions.explanation:
To find the equation of the line in slope-intercept form ($y = mx + b$):

1. **Identify the y-intercept ($b$):** The line crosses the y-axis at $(0, 3)$, so $b = 3$.
2. **Calculate the slope ($m$):** Use the two points $(0, 3)$ and $(3, 0)$.
$$m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} = \frac{0 - 3}{3 - 0} = \frac{-3}{3} = -1$$

Substitute $m = -1$ and $b = 3$ into the equation:
$$y = -1x + 3$$
$$y = -x + 3$$
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><path d='M0 30 H300 M0 60 H300 M0 90 H300 M0 120 H300 M0 150 H300 M0 180 H300 M0 210 H300 M0 240 H300 M0 270 H300' stroke='#f5f5f5' stroke-width='1'/><path d='M30 0 V300 M60 0 V300 M90 0 V300 M120 0 V300 M150 0 V300 M180 0 V300 M210 0 V300 M240 0 V300 M270 0 V300' stroke='#f5f5f5' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='150' y1='290' x2='150' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)'/><line x1='10' y1='150' x2='290' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)'/><text x='280' y='170' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='160' y='20' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>y</text><line x1='60' y1='30' x2='270' y2='240' stroke='#999' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><circle cx='150' cy='60' r='5' fill='black'/><circle cx='240' cy='150' r='5' fill='black'/><path d='M 150 60 V 150' stroke='red' stroke-width='3' fill='none'/><text x='135' y='110' font-size='14' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>-3</text><path d='M 150 150 H 240' stroke='green' stroke-width='3' fill='none'/><text x='195' y='170' font-size='14' fill='green' font-weight='bold'>+3</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same graph showing the calculation of the slope. A red vertical line moves down 3 units (rise = -3) and a green horizontal line moves right 3 units (run = +3), demonstrating why the slope is -1.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check the slope direction first. Lines going down from left to right have a **negative** slope. This immediately eliminates options with positive slopes.

questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>?
questions.explanation: First expand the squared term: <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>6</mn></msup><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Then multiply by <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>: <math><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>6</mn></msup><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>8</mn></msup><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember to square the coefficient as well as the variables. (2x)^2 is 4x^2, not 2x^2.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: A local bakery sells bagels for $2.00 each and muffins for $3.50 each. One morning, the bakery sold a total of 50 items (bagels and muffins) and earned a total of $145. If <math><mi>b</mi></math> represents the number of bagels sold and <math><mi>m</mi></math> represents the number of muffins sold, which system of equations represents this situation?
questions.explanation: The total count of items is 50, so <math><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></math>. The total revenue is calculated by price times quantity: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi></math> (revenue from bagels) + <math><mn>3.5</mn><mi>m</mi></math> (revenue from muffins) = 145.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Create two separate equations: one for the 'quantity' of items and one for the 'value' or cost of those items.

questions.question: A group of 80 students was surveyed about their preferred science subject. The data showed that 32 students preferred Biology, 24 preferred Chemistry, and the rest preferred Physics. If a student is selected at random from the group, what is the probability that the student preferred Physics? (Enter your answer as a decimal).
questions.explanation: First, find the number of students who preferred Physics: <math><mn>80</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>32</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></math>. The probability is the part over the whole: <math><mfrac><mn>24</mn><mn>80</mn></mfrac></math>. Dividing 24 by 80 gives <math><mn>0.3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always ensure you calculate the 'target' group correctly (subtraction) before creating the probability fraction.

questions.question: For the function <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>x</mi></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> into the function: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Calculate the exponent first: <math><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. Then multiply: <math><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>48</mn></math>. Finally add 5: <math><mn>48</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>53</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Follow the order of operations strictly (PEMDAS): Exponents before Multiplication, then Addition.

questions.question: The equation of a circle in the xy-plane is <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>. What is the radius of this circle?
questions.explanation: The standard equation of a circle is <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Here, <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>. Taking the square root gives <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the right side of the circle equation represents r-squared, not the diameter or the radius itself.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question:
In the system of equations below, k is a constant. If the system has infinitely many solutions, what is the value of k?
3x+ky=12
x+4y=4
questions.explanation: For a system to have infinitely many solutions, the equations must be equivalent (represent the same line). Notice that the constant term in the first equation (12) is 3 times the constant in the second equation (4). Therefore, the coefficients of x and y must also be 3 times larger. The coefficient of x in the first equation (3) is indeed 3 times the coefficient of x in the second (1). Thus, <math><mi>k</mi></math> must be 3 times 4, which is 12.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Compare the ratio of coefficients. For infinitely many solutions, a1/a2 = b1/b2 = c1/c2.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: The system of equations <math><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math> and <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> has no solution. If <math><mi>a</mi></math> is a constant, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: For a system to have no solution, the lines must be parallel, meaning they have the same slope but different y-intercepts. This implies the ratio of x-coefficients must equal the ratio of y-coefficients: <math><mfrac><mi>a</mi><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></math>. Solving for <math><mi>a</mi></math> gives <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. We also verify that the constant terms do not have the same ratio: <math><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>10</mn></mfrac><mo>≠</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>, confirming there is no solution.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Parallel lines have the same slope. If the slopes are same but constants differ, there is no solution.

questions.question: How many distinct real solutions does the equation <math><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> have?
questions.explanation: Use the discriminant <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi></math>. Here <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. Discriminant = <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>72</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>47</mn></math>. Since the discriminant is negative, there are no real solutions.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Calculate b^2 - 4ac. Positive = 2 solutions, Zero = 1 solution, Negative = 0 real solutions.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: A biologist is studying the population growth of a bacteria culture. The population, <math><mi>P</mi></math>, can be modeled by the function <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>500</mn><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.04</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>t</mi></msup></math>, where <math><mi>t</mi></math> represents time in hours. Which of the following best describes the population growth?

options.A: The population increases by 4% every hour.
options.B: The population increases by 104% every hour.
options.C: The population increases by 4 bacteria every hour.
options.D: The population increases by 1.04 bacteria every hour.

questions.explanation: In an exponential model <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>t</mi></msup></math>, <math><mi>r</mi></math> represents the growth rate. Here, the base is <math><mn>1.04</mn></math>, which is <math><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0.04</mn></math>. This corresponds to a growth rate of 0.04, or 4%.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If the base of the exponent is greater than 1, it's growth. Subtract 1 from the base to find the percentage rate.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='200' viewBox='0 0 400 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><path d='M 50,150 L 50,80 L 120,150 Z' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='50' y='140' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='35' y='75' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='125' y='160' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='35' y='160' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>C</text><path d='M 200,150 L 200,40 L 310,150 Z' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='200' y='140' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='185' y='35' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>D</text><text x='315' y='160' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>E</text><text x='185' y='160' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>F</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two right-angled triangles positioned side-by-side. The left triangle is labeled ABC with the right angle at C and the top vertex at A. The right triangle is larger, labeled DEF, with the right angle at F and the top vertex at D.
questions.question: Triangles $ABC$ and $DEF$ are similar right triangles, where angle $C$ and angle $F$ are the right angles. If $\sin(A) = \frac{5}{13}$, what is the value of $\cos(E)$?
questions.explanation:
Follow the logic step-by-step:

1. **Similarity:** Because $\triangle ABC \sim \triangle DEF$, corresponding angles are equal. Therefore, $m\angle A = m\angle D$. This means $\sin(D) = \sin(A) = \frac{5}{13}$.

2. **Trigonometry definitions:** In the right triangle $DEF$:
* $\sin(D) = \frac{\text{Opposite}}{\text{Hypotenuse}} = \frac{EF}{DE}$
* $\cos(E) = \frac{\text{Adjacent}}{\text{Hypotenuse}}$

3. **Connection:** Observe that side $EF$ is **opposite** to angle $D$, but it is **adjacent** to angle $E$. Therefore:
$$\cos(E) = \frac{EF}{DE} = \sin(D)$$

Since $\sin(D) = \frac{5}{13}$, then $\cos(E) = \frac{5}{13}$.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='200' viewBox='0 0 400 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><path d='M 150,150 L 150,40 L 260,150 Z' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='150' y='140' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='135' y='35' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>D</text><text x='265' y='160' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>E</text><text x='135' y='160' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='16'>F</text><text x='220' y='90' font-size='14' fill='blue'>Hypotenuse (13)</text><text x='180' y='175' font-size='14' fill='red' text-anchor='middle'>Side EF (5)</text><path d='M 155,50 Q 180,100 180,145' stroke='red' stroke-width='1' fill='none' marker-end='url(#arrow)' stroke-dasharray='4,4'/><text x='200' y='120' font-size='12' fill='red'>Opposite to D</text><path d='M 250,145 Q 220,145 190,155' stroke='green' stroke-width='1' fill='none' marker-end='url(#arrow)' stroke-dasharray='4,4'/><text x='220' y='140' font-size='12' fill='green'>Adjacent to E</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Triangle DEF is shown. Side DE is labeled 'Hypotenuse (13)'. Side EF is labeled 'Side EF (5)'. Annotations show that Side EF acts as the 'Opposite' side for angle D, but the 'Adjacent' side for angle E.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the **Complementary Angle Identity**: For any right triangle with acute angles $x$ and $y$, $\sin(x) = \cos(y)$.

questions.question: What is the positive solution to the equation <math><msqrt><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Square both sides: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Expand: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Rearrange to form a quadratic: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Factor: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Possible solutions are 4 and -3. Checking x=-3: <math><msqrt><mn>4</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math> (False). Checking x=4: <math><msqrt><mn>25</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math> (True). The positive solution is 4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always check for extraneous solutions when solving radical equations by plugging answers back into the original equation.

questions.question: A shipping company charges $4.50 per pound for standard shipping and $8.00 per pound for express shipping. A customer wants to ship at least 15 pounds of goods but can spend no more than $100. If <math><mi>s</mi></math> is the weight in pounds for standard shipping and <math><mi>e</mi></math> is the weight in pounds for express shipping, which system of inequalities represents these conditions?
questions.explanation: Total weight is <math><mi>s</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>e</mi></math>, and 'at least 15' means <math><mo>≥</mo><mn>15</mn></math>. Total cost is <math><mn>4.50</mn><mi>s</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8.00</mn><mi>e</mi></math>, and 'no more than 100' means <math><mo>≤</mo><mn>100</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Translate 'at least' to ≥ (greater than or equal) and 'no more than' to ≤ (less than or equal).

questions.question: A system of equations consists of the line <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and the parabola <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. At which point(s) do the graphs intersect?
questions.explanation: Set the equations equal: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Rearrange: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Factor: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Solutions are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Substitute back to find y: For <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. For <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When equating a linear and quadratic function, move all terms to one side to form a quadratic equation equal to zero.

questions.question: Two cylinders are similar. The surface area of cylinder A is <math><mn>50</mn><mi>π</mi></math> square units and the surface area of cylinder B is <math><mn>200</mn><mi>π</mi></math> square units. If the volume of cylinder A is <math><mn>100</mn><mi>π</mi></math> cubic units, what is the volume of cylinder B?
questions.explanation: The ratio of surface areas is <math><mfrac><mn>200</mn><mn>50</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. This is the square of the scale factor (<math><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>), so the linear scale factor <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. The ratio of volumes is the cube of the scale factor: <math><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. The volume of cylinder B is <math><mn>8</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>100</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>800</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If scale factor is k, Area ratio is k^2 and Volume ratio is k^3.

questions.question: For all positive values of <math><mi>a</mi></math> and <math><mi>b</mi></math>, which expression is equivalent to <math><mfrac><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mfrac><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>?
questions.explanation: Simplify the second term: <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></math>. Multiply by first term: <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>×</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></math>. Note: <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mfrac><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></math>. Add exponents for a: <math><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. Add exponents for b: <math><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Result: <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>0</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Apply the rule (xy)^n = x^n y^n and x^a * x^b = x^(a+b) systematically.
